dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men in shorts and Hawaiian shirts are poking around a sandy section in the middle of scrub flats. SERGEANT CLIF POTTS is in the f.g., a plant-and-tree guidebook in hand, SERGEANT "MIKEY" HOGAN works a metal detector over a larg sandy bank in the b.g.  Both are Army career men with a  morning off to pursue their hobbies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got ocotillo, devil's walking  stick--what's this stuff--it's that  whattayoucallit--horse-crippler. Mikey bends to scoop something out of the sand, putting i in a canvas bag slung on his hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is a gold mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lead mine. MIKEY sees that Cliff is talking, pulls his headset off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lead mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I'm talking to you,  you've got that thing on your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finding lots of cactus and shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not just cactus.  There's the  nopals, the yuccas--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Puts headset on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a lot of cactus to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grumbles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man knows a hundred-fifty varieties  of beer, he can't tell a poinsettia   from a prickly pear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Troubled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live in a place, you should know  something about it. Explore--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff--

dialogues.speaker: CU MIKEY
dialogues.text: MIKEY in the f.g. now, looking down at something as he pu his headset off again--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff, you gotta look at this-- Cliff wearily turns and approaches from the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me--Spanish treasure,  right?  Pieces of eight from the   Coronado expedition-- He stops by Mikey and looks down, his expression changing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus--

dialogues.speaker: GROUND
dialogues.text: Sticking out from the sand bank are the SKELETAL BONES of MAN'S HAND.  There is a ring on one finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was Coronado in the Masons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distant cloud of DUST appears on the horizon MUSIC  underscores that we are in Texas, and we SUPERIMPOSE the  OPENING CREDITS as the dust takes form around an APPROACH CAR.  The car comes close enough to see it has a County  Sheriff's insignia on the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see SAM DEEDS, the Sheriff, driving. Sam is 40, quietl competent to the point of seeming a bit moody. He sees  something up ahead. MUSIC, CREDITS END as Sam pulls off the road and we see t sergeants standing in the scrub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hand and forearm down to the elbow of the skeleton ar visible now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff stands looking at the arm with Sam. MIKEY is a few  yards behind them, playing with his metal detector. Beyon him we see the Sheriff's car parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was driving back from Apache Wells  when they got me on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was a rifle range way back when.  But we figured it isn't Army land  anymore, it's your jurisdiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the forensics fella coming  down from the Rangers. No way to   know how old the body is without  some lab work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ring--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masons been around a long while. Mikey has come up to them, still sweeping with the metal  detector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treasure hunter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Apologetic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old bullets.  He uhm-- makes art  with them. Sam just nods. Mikey frowns, goes down on one knee and  scratches something out of the dirt at their feet--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff says we shouldn't touch  anything,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't hear with that rig on--  Mikey! Mikey comes up with something, holds it before them. An  encrusted piece of metal--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What've we got here? Sam takes the thing, lays it back down where Mikey found

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'posed to leave everything right  where we found it. They're real  particular about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene of the crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No telling yet if there's been a  crime. Sam frowns down at the piece of metal as he rubs the face it.

dialogues.speaker: CU METAL
dialogues.text: Sam's thumb wipes across the face of the encrusted metal. is roughly star-shaped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this country's seen a good number  of disagreements over the years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look at a beautiful old pull-down map of Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do the best we can here-- A teacher in her late 30s, PILAR CRUZ, steps in front of map and we FOLLOW her across the room, carrying a poster

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but hey, public education these  days is a bit of a battleground. Posters hung on the walls beyond her show luminaries from Texas history-- Sam Houston, Stephen Austin, Juan Seguin. new parent, CELIE PAYNE, stands in the middle of the othe empty classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went to school on base when we  were in Okinawa. It's all--you know-- kids in the same boat--Army brats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His record shows that he's a good  student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm more worried about the social  thing. Are therelike--gangs, or...? PILAR starts to put the poster up. CELIE moves to hold it place for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't had any serious violence,  if that's what you mean. We've got a  pretty lively mix though--you walk  into the cafeteria and the Anglo  kids are in one section, the Mexican  kids in another and the Black kids  have a table in the back--thanks--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Blacks are--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're the smallest group except  for a couple Kickapoo kids. Look,  you're obviously a concerned parent.  Chet has no history of getting into  trouble--I'm happy to have him in my  class. She steps back to see if the poster, an old photo of Gero looks straight. Another teacher, MOLLY sticks her head in the door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar, is uhm--is Amado okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay? He's not here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Is he sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mutters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to wish he was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the door of a deluxe pickup truck is an airbrushed pic of a Pancho Villa-looking vaquero with bandoliers crossin his chest and a gun blazing in each hand. We hear LOUD MU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luis! Give me that Phillips-head  back--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small group of teenage Chicano BOYS hang around the tru in the bed, on the hood, leaning against it. A BOOMBOX pl on top of the cab blasts RANCHA MUSIC out at the neighbor Somebody's legs are hanging out the open passenger-side d The kids suddenly look as a Sheriff's Department car slid into the f.g.  A Deputy Sheriff, TRAVIS, gets out.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Trying to look tough and unworried as we TRACK across the street toward them. Travis's hand reaches out from behind the camera to flick the MUSIC OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMADO CRUZ, Pilar's 15-year-old son, lies on the front se installing a compact disc player into the dash slot. He  reaches up to the dash, can't find what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody hand me the CD player--  damelo pendejos-- He looks up and we TILT to see Travis leaning in the wind examining the new radio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come a long way from those old  8-track jobs, haven't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Waves radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is stolen property. Alla you  fellas are coming down to the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweat beads the forehead of a thin, tired-looking recent  immigrant, ENRIQUE, as he delivers platters of chile rell to a booth. MEXICAN MUSIC plays on a jukebox in the b.g. HOLD on the booth, where HOLLIS POGUE, in his 60s enterta two GOOD OLD BOYS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Buddy walks up to the porch and  there's old Fishbait McHenry, cleanin'  the dirt out his toenails with a  pocketknife--he was the most hygienic  of all the McHenrys-- The breakfast companions are laughing already--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Fishbait," says Buddy, in that quiet  way of his, "What you know about  them tires that went missing from  markets?" Fishbait thinks for a  minute, then he lifts up a loose  board from the porch floor and calls  down into it, "C'mon out, Pooter,  they caught us!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy Deeds. He had a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He known who it was onnacouna the  tire tracks in the dirt from the  back of the garage to where they  loaded up. "Old Fishbait," he says,  "never lifted a thing in this world  if there was a way he could roll  it." More laughter--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't be another like him. That boy  of his doesn't come near it. You ask  me, he's all hat and no cattle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellas-- We WIDEN to see Sam standing by their booth. No telling h long he's been listening, Fenton is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam! I was just telling a few about  your old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a unique individual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was that. We sense a little strain when Sam has to talk about his f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big day coming up--I wish we'd have  thought of it while he was still  living. But he went so unexpected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better late than never. Korean War  hero, Sheriff for near thirty years--  Buddy Deeds Memorial P--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard there was a bit of a fuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, the usual troublemakers.  Danny Padilla from the Sentinel,  that crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every other damn thing in the country  is called after Martin Luther King,  they can't let our side have one  measly park?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King wasn't Mexican, Fenton--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad enough all the street names are  in Spanish--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were here first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then name it after Big Chief  Shitinabucket! Whoever that Tonkawa  fella was. He had the Mexes beat by  centuries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a faction pulling for that  boy who was killed in the Gulf War--  Ruben--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Santiago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. But nobody here ever noticed  him till they read his name on the  national news--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just wanted it to be one of  theirs--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the whole story. The  Mexicans that know, that remember,  understand what Buddy was for their  people.  Hell, it was Mercedes over  there who swung the deciding vote  for him. Sam looks to the register where Pilar's mother, MERCEDES  CRUZ, whacks rolls of change apart on the counter. She se to be avoiding looking toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She put it even at three to three,  so as the Mayor I get to cast the  tiebreaker. The older generation  won't have any problem with it. They  remember how Buddy come to be Sheriff,  that it was all 'cause he took their  part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that one, Hollis--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, everybody heard that story a  million times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to hear it. Your version of  it. Something about the way Sam says it puts Hollis on guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Hollis.

dialogues.speaker: CU HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Hollis is hooked into it now--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of us were the only deputies  back then me and Buddy--it's what--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '57, 1 believe--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Sheriff at the time was Big  Charley Wade. Charley was one of  your old-fashioned bribe-or-bullets  kind of Sheriffs, he took a healthy  bite out of whatever moved through  this county. He looks down at the table--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in here one night, back  when  Jimmy Herrera run the place.   Started  right here in this booth. We PAN down to the table, The food has changed. The torti are in a straw basket instead of plastic. The jukebox cha to ANOTHER SONG and the LIGHT DIMS slightly. A hand with big Masonic ring on one finger appears to lift a tortilla underneath it lie three ten-dollar bills.  The hand lifts them up and we TILT to see the face of SHERIFF CHARLEY WA a big, mean redneck with shrewd eyes. It is 1957--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This beaner fare doesn't agree with  me, but the price sure is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade sits across from his young deputies, YOUNG HOLLIS (3 and BUDDY DEEDS (20s). A chicken-fried steak sits untouch in front of Buddy. Hollis has the anxious look of an erra boy, while Buddy is self-contained and quietly forceful f his age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy got a kitchen full of wetbacks,  most of 'em relatives. People breed  like chickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I roust some muchacho on the street,  doesn't have his papers, all he got  to say is "Yo trabajo para Jimmy  Herrera." Wade folds the money and stuffs if in his pocket--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to keep the wheels greased,  son. Sheriff does his job right,  everybody makes out. Now this is  gonna be one of your pickups, Buddy.  First of the month, just like the  rent. Get the car, Hollis. Wade and Hollis slide out of the booth to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing it. Hollis stops a few feet away, shocked. Wade just stares d at Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come again? Buddy looks Wade in the eye, seemingly unafraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your deal. You sweated it out  of him, you pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's gonna be some left over for  you, Buddy. I take care of my boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feeling bad for Jimmy? Have him  tell you the size of the mordida  they took out of his hide when he  run a place on the other side. Those  old boys in Ciudad Leon--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not picking it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do whatever I say you do or else  you put it on the trail, son. The CUSTOMERS are all watching now, nervous. Buddy thinks for a moment, not taking his eyes off Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout this--how 'bout you put  that shield on this table and  vanish  before you end up dead or in jail? Wade rests his hand on his pistol.  It is dead silent but for the MUSIC on the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever shoot anybody was looking  you in the eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said anything about shootin'  anybody? Buddy has his gun out under the table.  He slowly brings up and lays it flat on the table, not taking his hand off or his eyes off Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whole different story; isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired. You're outta the  department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not a soul in this county  isn't sick to death of your bullshit,  Charley. You made yourself scarce,  you could make a lot of people happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little pissant--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now or later, Charley. You won't  have any trouble finding me. Wade feels the people around him waiting for a reaction. leans close to Buddy to croak in a hoarse whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a dead man. He turns and nearly bumps into Hollis. He gives the Deput shove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the goddamn car. We're going to  Roderick's.

dialogues.speaker: CU BUDDY
dialogues.text: He watches till the screen door shuts behind them, then  holsters his gun and begins to saw at the steak as if not had happened. He calls softly--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muchacho--mas cerveza por favor. He looks up at somebody and we PAN till we see Sam, still standing over the booth, listening. We are back in 1995--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mas cerveza por favor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Buddy was a cool breeze. We PULL BACK to see Hollis and his buddies at the table,  eating their lunches as they listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley Wade were known to have put  a good number of people in the ground,  and your daddy gets eyeball to eyeball  with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made our collection at Roderick's  place and that was the last anybody  seen hide nor hair of him.  He went  missing the next day, along with ten  thousand dollars in county funds  from the safe at the jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard from him again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a peep. Buddy run the man out of  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy Deeds said a thing, he damn  well backed it up. Won't be another  like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he arrested all of Jimmy Herrera's  people and sent 'em back to the other  side? Hollis sees what Sam is getting at, grins--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh--he come to an accommodation.  Money doesn't always need to change  hands to keep the wheels turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know you had some problems  with your father, and he and Muriel--  well--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother was a saint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but Buddy Deeds was my salvation. Sam nods, speaks softly--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't be another like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLONEL DELMORE PAYNE (DEL), a very direct, by-the-book B officer, addresses them. Artillery pieces angle toward th sky behind him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --it's an honor for me to assume  command of this unit, and I look  forward to working with all of you. OFFICERS Cliff and Mikey, in uniform now, flank SERGEANT  PRISCILLA WORTH, a Black woman in her early 40s, as they  stand in formation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're all aware of the  Army's decision to close this  installation under the Reduction in  Force plan. That does not mean,  however--

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: We look over the shoulders of assembled OFFICERS and NCOs toward Del.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --that we've been sent here to mark  time until we are absorbed by another  unit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have heard rumors that I run  a very tight operation. These rumors  are not exaggerated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking through a magnifying glass at an old photo Buddy's face is slightly distorted by the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam? I got Danny Padilla from the  paper for you-- Sam sits at his desk in the Sheriff's office, looking dow at the photo--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'll catch him later.

dialogues.speaker: CU PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: An old photo of the 1957 Sheriff's Department officers on the courthouse steps. Wade, Hollis, Buddy, a few others, in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he needs to talk to you before  the ceremony, Sam. Sam puts a magnifying glass over the photo and bends clos to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to try me tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: EXTREME CU PHOTO
dialogues.text: MAGNIFIED POV of the badge on Wade's chest swims into vie A metal star. We hear the secretary getting rid of the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks you're trying to duck   him.

dialogues.speaker: CU SAM
dialogues.text: Looking at the photo, troubled--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mutters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start on a BLINKING SIGN--BIG O'S, then PAN to see a f parking lot outside the low, neon-lit roadhouse. R&B blasts from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHET, a Black kid around 15, stands nervously at the door building up his courage.  He takes a deep breath, plunges in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TRACK with Chet, very nervous, as he makes his way thr the crowded roadhouse. The customers are all Black, many  from the nearby Army post, SHOUTING and LAUGHING over the loud MUSIC. Chet, edgy, is looking for somebody.  He sees

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Seen through the crush is OTIS "BIG O" PAYNE, a large man his early 60s, laughing as he stands behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: He nervously puts his hand under his jacket. A gun? He pu forward to get a better view.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Moving in on him. Otis looks over, sees the boy, frowns--

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Reaching under his jacket, he pulls out--a photograph. He looks at it--suddenly there is a SCREAM from behind, then GUNSHOTS, patrons diving for the floor. Chet whirls around and we WHIP PAN to see a young man, SH emptying his pistol into RICHIE, a young soldier, as a yo woman, ATHENA, screams and tries to pull the gun away. Wi the last shot, Shadow turns and heads for the door, but i tackled and swarmed by angry men, SHOUTING. We PAN to Athena, kneeling over the bleeding, twitching b of Richie--

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Chet backs up, horrified. A large hand grasps him on the  shoulder from behind. He turns to see Otis standing over  him, strangely calm amid the chaos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't in here tonight, were   you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go out through the back. Chet hurries away.  Otis watches him for a moment, then t to the mess in his club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An angry woman stands from her auditorium chair--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just tearin' everything  down!   Tearin' down our heritage, tearin'  down the memory of people that fought  and died for this land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fought and died for this land,  too! We WHIP PAN to see another standing parent--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fought the U.S. Army, the Texas  Rangers--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you lost, buddy! We WHIP PAN to a man in the rear--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winners get the bragging rights,  that's how it goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People--people--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the High School auditorium, a hot-and-heavy tea and-parents meeting in progress. Pilar sits at the end of long table facing the agitated parents, taking some heat. DANNY PADILLA, a young, long-haired reporter, sits in the front taking notes, enjoying the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it would be best not to put  things in terms of winners and losers--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Points at Pilar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the way she's teachin' it has  got everything switched around. I  was on the textbook committee, and  her version is not--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think of the textbook as kind of  a guide, not an absolute--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --it is not what we set as the  standard! Now you people can believe  what you want, but when it comes to  teaching our children--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're our children, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men who founded this state have  a right to have their story--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men who founded this state broke  from Mexico because they needed  slavery to be legal to make a fortune  in the cotton business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's a bit of an  oversimplification--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you reporting this meeting or  runnin' it, Danny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just adding a little historical  perspective--

dialogues.speaker: REAR OF AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: PALOMA CRUZ, Pilar's teenage daughter, peeks into the roo then moves down the side toward the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may call it history, but I call  it propaganda. I'm sure they got  their own account of the Alamo on  the other side, but we're not on the  other side, so we're not about to  have it taught in our schools!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no reason to be so threatened  by this-- Pilar is trying to stay calm despite her anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only been trying to get across  some of the complexity of our  situation down here--cultures coming  together in both negative and positive  ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you mean like music and food and  all, I have no problem with that.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: We shoot past Pilar toward the parents in their seats. PA steps up to whisper to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but when you start changing who  did what to who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not changing anything, we're  presenting a more complete picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's what's got to stop! Pilar looks troubled by what she's heard. She shoots a lo toward the others at the table, then slips away with Palo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's enough ignorance in the world  without us encouraging it in the  classroom--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now who are you calling ignorant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Folks, I know this is a very emotional  issue for some of you, but we do  have other business to attend to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to get some resolution  on this?

dialogues.speaker: CU PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Weary--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you people like to form another  committee? GROANS from the parents--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shadow, face bruised, hands cuffed behind him, is pushed through the door to be booked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope the sucker does die, man!  Mess with me, that's what you get! Sam steps in behind him and meets his Chief Deputy RAY  HERNANDEZ, coming from the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hospital says the other kid is in  bad shape--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Glances ahead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shooter local?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shakes his bead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down from Houston. I think he knew  the girl before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay--we'll take a statement from  all the GIs before they go back to  post. You can get the story from  Otis over at the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any poop on the John Doe you found  out there today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' much. The Rangers put Ben  Wetzel on it. Catch you later. As Ray steps out, Pilar looking distraught, walks into th station, passing right by Sam without seeing him.

dialogues.speaker: CU SAM
dialogues.text: Wonders what she's doing there--

dialogues.speaker: PILAR
dialogues.text: She stands by an unoccupied reception desk, very upset, u to attract anyone's attention because of the activity aro the shooting.  She looks tired and a bit scared under the harsh overhead light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar.

dialogues.speaker: PILAR AND SAM
dialogues.text: Pilar looks around. Sam is standing by her. We can tell t is some history between these two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got my Amado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got him here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody called--something about an  electronics store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see what's going on. He starts away, stops, comes back--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was--I was real sorry about Nando.  He was a good fella. We haven't talked  since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't talked since high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'll go check on your boy. Pilar watches Sam go--

dialogues.speaker: REAR OF OFFICE
dialogues.text: Travis sits typing away at a word processor as Athena, in tears, gives testimony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --so Richie just didn't say nothin'  'cause he didn't want to get into  it, see, and the next thing I know  there's shots and Richie is down. It  happened so fast--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me-- We WIDEN to see Sam standing over the desk--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got some boys you run in earlier  today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I pulled the bunch that hangs  at Pico Bernal's place. We finally  caught them with something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a juvenile with 'ern--Amado  Cruz? Travis looks at his booking sheets--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah--let's see--the other ones say  he wasn't in on the theft, he just  knows how to hook things up. We've  been trying to contact a parent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks with Amado, who is trying to look defiant--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell me you're good at fixing  things. Nothin--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father was a hell of a mechanic. Still nothing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, if you figure minimum wage  on the time most thieves spend in  jail, they could have bought most  everything they stole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't steal anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say you did. My name is  Sam, by the way. Amado just gives him a look--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and AMADO step out into the office, where Pilar stand waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what the big deal is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find out when I get you home.  Thanks, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. Pilar yanks AMADO outside by his arm. She turns to shoot look back at Sam, then steps out through the glass door.

dialogues.speaker: CU SAM
dialogues.text: Watching her go--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OBSTACLE COURSE
dialogues.text: We shoot up from a pit in the ground. WHUMP! WHUMP! WHUMP Three men leap over, landing on the far side and running  away from us.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: Del Payne runs with Cliff and Mikey on a pathway along a  security fence, the two sergeants struggling to keep up,  occasionally vaulting or scaling some mild obstacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not that much down here,  Colonel. Big O's is the only place  in the county that our African  American soldiers are uhm--that they  feel comfortable in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we had trouble there before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I've been stationed here? A  fistfight now and then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a kid pass out in the men's  room. The town isn't much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't come for a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how it is, Colonel--first  time away from home, dealing with  new people--I remember my first hitch--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Substance abuse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, but I went through the  Program. I haven't had a drink since--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant on the post. In general. How  are you dealing with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We throw a urine test at them once a  month. Random numbers, maybe a hundred  people at a time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we make it once a week for  a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem, sir. Del notices bow hard they are breathing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sprint the last quarter mile. You  gentlemen don't have to keep up if  you don't care to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appreciate it, sir. Del accelerates and we HOLD with the sergeants, slowing t near-walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy cracks walnuts with his asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get the feeling he doesn't want  to be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Hank Williams' gospel song "I'll Have a New Body  (I'll Have a New Life)" as we see the gathered bones of t skeleton tagged and photographed and measured, impression made of the dental work in the skull, photographs of the  excavation of the body at various stages marked with red  grease pencil, the piece of metal laid in a de-tarnishing dish, the ring put under a microscope.

dialogues.speaker: CU METAL
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES as we TIGHTEN on the piece of metal, a pa of tongs pulling it from the de-tarnishing solution. It i star-shaped badge, bearing the words "SHERIFF--RIO COUNTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C&W MUSIC playing, the regulars starting to show up. makes his way to a table where BEN WETZEL, a Texas Ranger sits with a file of forensic reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam the Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ben. Thanks for coming down. They shake, Sam sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business is booming. Got your drugs,  got your illegals--had a shooting  the other night at Big O's--Soldier  got ventilated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear they're closing that post  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September '97, that's all she wrote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna pull a lot of jobs out of this  county.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll have folks swimming over  to Mexico to work in the sweatshops. Sam looks at the folder of reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the word on our boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is Skinny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skinny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find a body, it's either Skinny  or Stinky, depending on how much  meat there is on the bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Opens folder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Male, 40 to 50 years old, five-foot- eleven, chewed tobacco--then we get  into the dental records--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That badge--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --it didn't come out of a cereal  box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the popular version of how  he left town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody on the border knows that  story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a cause of death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skull was intact, no soft tissue  left--not much to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he could have gone out to the  base, hopped the fence, dug down  into the dirt on the old rifle range  and had a heart attack. Ben smiles, closes the folder--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You uhm--you remember what old Buddy  carried for a side arm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colt Peacemaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swore by it. (Ben frowns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is Buddy on your short list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was some poor mojado, swam  across at night, got lost in the  scrub and starved out there, we  wouldn't go any further. But this is  a formerly prominent citizen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to investigate. No question  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I will do is keep names out of  it till we got some answers or hit a  dead end. You know how the press is  with a murder story--even if it's  forty years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a pretty cold trail. They sit in awkward silence for a moment. Ben feels bad a it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember Charley Wade come to my  father's hardware store once when I  was a little boy. I'd heard stories  how he shot this one, how he shot  that one--man winked at me and I  peed in my pants. (Shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winked at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar stands at the blackboard by her outline of 19th cen Texas history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we have the fight against the  Spanish with bloody conflict for  dozens of years till they're finally  defeated in 1821 and Mexican  independence is declared. Anglo  settlers are invited--

dialogues.speaker: CU DRAWING
dialogues.text: Somebody making a skillful pencil drawing on the corner o sheet of lined notebook paper. A bald, muscular shotputte after releasing the shot, his hand large in the f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --to colonize the area and by the  time they begin the movement against  Santa Anna they outnumber the Mexicans  here by four to one. The war between  Mexico--

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Drawing intently. He takes the notebook and lays his thum over the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and the Anglo forces ends in 1836  with the formation of the Texas  Republic. Texas joins the United  States as a state where slavery is  legal in 1845--

dialogues.speaker: NOTEBOOK
dialogues.text: Chet "flips" the corner of the notebook and the series of drawings he's made form a brief cartoon of the shot-putte blowing his cheeks out and heaving the shot right past us Extremely well-drawn--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: after the so-called Mexican war and  then secedes to join the Confederacy  in 1861. The Confederacy is beaten,  and the Reformation period here is  marked by range wars and race wars--

dialogues.speaker: PILAR
dialogues.text: Looking out at the class--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and all this paralleled by constant  battles between both the Mexican and  Anglo settlers and the various Indian  nations in the area. What are we  seeing here? Chet?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Startled, he hides the notebook under his hands --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm--everybody is killing everybody  else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nasty-looking thing. Only a bass would want to eat this Hollis leans in to peer at the thing dangling before his  face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis sits in the swivel chair of a bass boat tied to a  dock at the lake, going through his box of lures. Sam app on the dock and steps down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always wondered what you Mayors do  when you're not cutting ribbons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam! Hey podner! You caught me playing  hooky--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks across lake)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floating around out here, playin'  hell with them bass--play a little  cards, play a little golf, drink  some beer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds great. Where do I sign up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been out here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go by your old house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as well. The new people just  painted it some God-awful color--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found a body out by the Army base  yesterday. Been there for a long  time. Hollis squints at a rubber lure, rejects it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it Davy Crockett or Jim Bowie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You recall if Charley Wade was a  Mason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley? I believe he was. Used to  go for lodge meetings over to Laredo.  What's he got to do with your body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All it was wearing was a big old  Masonic ring and a Rio County Sheriffs  badge. Hollis reacts. Sam puts a foot on the gunwale of the boat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember anything else  from that last night you saw him, do  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the story enough times--hell,  we were just in the car, he was  stewing about the fight with Buddy  while we drove over to Roderick  Bledsoe's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bledso

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owned the colored roadhouse before  Big O--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I think his widow's still in  their place in Darktown, though. (Shakes his bead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's Charley Wade, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forensics people are sure of it. You  have any idea who might have put him  there? Hollis makes a great show of considering--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides my father, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no call for that, Sam. Fella  made himself a pile of enemies over  the years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Buddy was one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got that dedication tomorrow.  This is a hell of a time to be  draggin' up old business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People have worked this whole big  thing up around my father. If it's  built on a crime, they deserve to  know. Now I understand why you might  want to believe he couldn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I understand why you might want  to think he could. This is a low blow, but accurate enough to shake Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your time, Hollis. Hollis holds up a double handful of lures--dozens of rubb and plastic worms and shiners and frogs and spinners--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at all this, would you? My  tackle, the boat, all to catch a  little old fish just minding its  business on the bottom of the lake. He gives Sam a look--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly seems worth the effort--does  it, Sam? Sam walks away--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Athena stands at attention, trying to keep her composure-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you knew this young man before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From back in Houston. We both come  up on Fifth Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know he was going to be there  last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had I wouldn't have gone in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you and Private Graves--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just dancing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff leans against a desk, a blackboard covered with rad diagrams behind him. Priscilla sits nearby, both of them  focused on Athena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not running a dating service  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, Sergeant. We were just  dancing. There was a bunch of us  there. Shadow just come down looking  for trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not our job to get involved in  your personal life, but when it  interferes with the training here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sergeant Major. There  wasn't anything I could do. Shadow  gets crazy-- A silence as the sergeant lets her stew for a moment. She works up her courage--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Major? How is Richie doing?  Private Graves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be transferred to a military  hospital as soon as he's stabilized--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll probably be getting a medical  discharge--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the Army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to lose a lung. This is  not good news for Athena--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will this go on my record? Cliff considers for a long moment--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the incident happened the way you  say it did, there hasn't been an  infraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sergeant Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sergeant Major. Athena steps out of the room. Cliff sits on the desk--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spoil 'em, Cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey--she's in a tough situation. I  cut her some slack--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm the one in charge of her  sorry ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's pulled herself out of a pretty  rough neighborhood. Crossing to the door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if she isn't careful she's gonna  slide right back into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start on a CU of a rocker creaking back and forth on a old wooden porch. A WOMAN HUMS.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: MINNIE BLEDSOE, in her 60s, sits on her porch in the old  Black section of town, playing with a Gameboy. She has ve thick glasses on. Sam walks up to her from his car--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bledsoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Sheriff Deeds--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Deeds' dead, honey--you just  Sheriff junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's the story of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever play one of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't ever start up on 'em,  cause once you do you can't stop. I  tell myself I'm gonna play just three  little games after breakfast, and  here I sit with half the day gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind if I ask a few questions  about your husband? Roderick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't say nothing bad about the  man, but you can ask away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had the club out on the old trail  road--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We run that twenty-odd years. Give  it over to Otis Payne in 1967. April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you must remember Sheriff Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I can help it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had to deal with him in running  the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them days, you deal with Sheriff  Wade or you didn't deal at all. First  of the month, every month, he remind  you of who you really workin' for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squeezed money out of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't legal to sell liquor in a  glass back then unless you was a  club, see. Roderick used to say,  "Buy yourself a drink, you get a  free membership." But Sheriff Wade,  he could shut you down anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Buddy was a different story.  Long as Roderick throw his weight  the right way on election day, make  sure all the colored get out to vote- we was called colored back then, if  you was polite--maybe throw a barbecue  for the right people now and then,  things was peaceful. That Sheriff  Wade, though, he took an awful big  bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People didn't complain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if they was colored or Meskin.  Not if they wanted to keep breathin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember the last time you  saw him? Minnie thinks, puts down the Gameboy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen him in our place the last  week before he gone missin'. We TRACK in to a close-up of her. R&B MUSIC FADES UP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He used to come in whilst we was in  full swing, make people nervous. Had  him a smile like the Grim Reaper--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joint is crowded, people drinking, talking, laughing, few dancing, all trying to avoid locking eyes with Sherif Wade, who sits with his legs stretched out at a table. Young Hollis sits by him, smiling uncomfortably. Sax-wail R&B blasts from the jukebox. YOUNG OTIS, a slick, con character with straightened hair and a silk shirt on, in early 20s, stops to talk with a MAN on his way to bring a tray with a couple beers and glasses over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --just sit back with his hand on  that big ol' gun and act the kingfish  with everybody. Otis Payne had come  to work for us by then, and that boy  had him some attitude--

dialogues.speaker: CU WADE
dialogues.text: Watching Young Otis with narrowed eyes--

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: A man puts a slip of paper in Otis's pocket, pats his bac Otis winks to acknowledge the bet, turns, makes eyes at a PRETTY WOMAN sitting at the bar, who is eyeing him back. lays the beers and glasses on the table, starts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pour it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pour it. Expressionless, he starts to pour the beer into Wade's gl The Sheriff looks up into his face--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Otis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Payne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Cleroe Payne's boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent your Daddy to the farm once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you think that was? Otis feels people watching.  He doesn't want to lose face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some crop needed pickin' and the man  was shorthanded. A very insolent answer for the time and place--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I remember it was because he had  a sassy mouth on him. Must run in  the family--You wouldn't be runnin'  numbers out of this club, now, would  you, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runnin' numbers illegal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runnin' numbers without I know about  it is both illegal and unhealthy.  You remember that. The beer is poured. Otis starts away--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoah, son. You're not finished.  Pour his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer it in the bottle--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Hollis. Pour. Otis meets Wade's look now, pours the other beer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you don't took familiar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been away. Up to Houston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Houston, huh? I hear they let you  boys run wild up there. No response. Wade deliberately pushes the glass away so b splashes on the table and drips into Hollis's lap--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw--look what you done now. Better  get something to wipe it up, son. Half the people in the room are watching now, the other h moving away to relative safety. Otis tries to keep a lid his temper, looks around the room--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spilt it, you wipe it up. Wade stands, steely-eyed, and looks at Otis nose to nose-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to do something. Are you  gonna hop to it, or are we gonna  have a problem? Otis is starting to shake, but holds his ground--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want to turn tail in front of  your people. I understand. He starts to turn away then WHAP! brings the butt of his  pistol up under Otis's chin, knocking him to the floor. A woman SCREAMS and Otis, enraged, grabs the chair he has f over, starts to get up--but Wade has the pistol levelled his face--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Houston, give it a try!  Come to Poppa-- RODERICK is out on the floor now, hands held out in a ges of peace, as YOUNG MINNIE watches from behind the bar,  petrified--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind him, Sheriff. Boy's just  a bit slow, is all. He don't mean  nothin' by it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the problem, son?  You Slow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis, apologize to the Sheriff-- Otis eases the chair down but doesn't say anything--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got him too scared to peep,  Sheriff. Maybe if you put that gun  up--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You telling me what to do, Roderick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sheriff, I'm just-- Wade looks around, widens his eyes in mock surprise--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this I see? Is that whiskey  in them glasses on the Bar? Roderick,  I'm gonna have to cite you for a  violation of state law--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a club, Sheriff--you been in  here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And people better clear out of here!  Now! A few people start for the exit.  Wade swivels and BLAM s a bullet past Minnie that shatters a crystal decanter beh the bar.  People run for the door. Wade squats down to lo Otis in the face--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You learn how to act your place,  son. This idn't Houston. He stands and we FOLLOW him toward the bar--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course I was young and full of beans  then-- The camera passes Wade and instead of Minnie there stands Otis, PRESENT DAY, reminiscing. We are back in '95--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't understand the spot I was  putting Roderick in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that was the last time you saw  him? We SHIFT to see Sam sitting where Wade was headed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh--I think he came in one more time  with Hollis and--naw, your Daddy  wasn't with them. Made their monthly  pickup. Roderick wasn't in so I just  kept my mouth good and shut and handed  over that envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the night he disappeared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could of been. That was white people's  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when my father was Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your deal with him? Otis smiles, chooses his words carefully--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy was more a part of the big  picture--county political machine,   chamber of commerce, zoning board if  I kept those people happy, he was  pretty much on my side. (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever somebody thought--they start  up another bar for the black  folks,  they'd be--how should I put this?  They'd be officially discouraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ever accept cash for a favor? Otis smiles, looks away to ponder his response--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't recall a prisoner ever died  in your father's custody. I don't  recall a man in this town--Black,  White, Mexican--who'd hesitate a  minute before they'd call on Buddy  Deeds to solve a problem. More than  that I wouldn't like to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar drives Amado and her daughter Paloma home--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you had your way I wouldn't have  any friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Amado--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just 'cause I'm not like Little Miss  Honor Roll here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave your sister out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and all of the teachers in this  dump--your story's over, so you don't  want anybody else to have fun. We see on PILAR's face that he has scored--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You jerk--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking to you. You don't  have any friends. PILAR eases the car down San Jacinto street, seeing somet on the street and she's tuning her kids' conversation out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd want to be friends with that  bunch of pachuco wannabes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't pretend I came over on the  Mayflower--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And those stupid girls who hang out  with them--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just shut up.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sam walks on the sidewalk parallel to them, talking with  three other MEN--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanie Orozco's telling the whole  school she's like desperately in  love with Santo Guerra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pathetic. You can't be  desperately in love when you're 14  years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar is still looking fixedly out the window--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you have half a brain in your  head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have anything to do with  being smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny Padilla is arguing with H.L. BRIGGS, a construction company big shot, and JORGE GUERRA, a Council member in h 40s and Sam, as they walk down the sidewalk of the main s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm saying is, I don't see the  point. You had your chance when the  dedication committee was meeting--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got new information--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ancient goddarn history, Danny--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1963, they dam up the north branch  to make Lake Pescadero. A whole little  town disappears--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squatter town--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People had been living in Perdido  for over a hundred years. Mexicans  and Chicanos are deported, evicted,  moved forcibly out of their houses  by our local hero, Buddy Deeds, and  his department--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a bill from the state  legislature--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Families were split apart, a whole  community was destroyed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were trespassing, Danny--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and who ends up with lakefront  property bought for a fraction of  the market price? Buddy Deeds, Sheriff  of Rio County, and his Chief Deputy,  Hollis Pogue. They all look at Sam, who has been listening patiently th whole while.  They've reached his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not after you, Sam.  I  just think people in town ought to  know the full story on Buddy Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes two of us. Sam steps into his office, leaving H.L. shaking his head-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You best be thankful that's the son  and not the father. Buddy woulda  kicked your ass from here to sundown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TRACK down a hallway as Celie walks toward us, calling ahead. Chet stands in the middle of the hall behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see what the big deal is. Go  back over, talk to the man, and bury  the hatchet, Del-- CELIE passes us and Del crosses back in the other directi from behind the camera, carrying boxes of their belonging We continue our SLOW TRACK forward--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis Payne was never embarrassed  about a thing in his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were 8 years old when he left--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't leave, he moved three houses  down with one of my mother's best  friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Hey, Delmore, where's your Daddy?" Del disappears into the bedroom at the end of the hall--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody else's business. And  everybody loved Big O-- DEL comes back out, empty-handed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big O was always there with a  smile  or a loan or a free drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, can I talk to you about track?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I talked to the track coach--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we already had this out?   Next year, if your grades are high  enough--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a B average.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many B-average students do you  think they take at West Point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we don't. Del steps away past us, leaving Chet, defeated--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start on Enrique, talking surreptitiously on the pay p on the way to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sabado por la noche--Is, es el  mas  seguero--a cruzar por la  manana y  pues tendremos que esperar--[Friday  night--Yes, that's the safest--I'll  cross in the morning and then we'll  have to wait--] Mercedes bustles by, snapping her fingers--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off the phone, by we've got people  waiting. Andale! We FOLLOW Mercedes back into the kitchen, where she moves through, kibbitzing the operation--

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Mercedes stops by a young girl prepping a pork loin to be cooked. She isn't wearing gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donde estan sus guantes? Tonta! Quiere  matar a mis clientes? [Where are  your gloves? Stupid! You want to  kill my customers?] She continues past, shaking her bead, bringing us to Pila who is trying to stay out of the way--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These ones coming up are getting  stupider every year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're just getting less  patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they're going to survive here,  they have to know how to work, Elalco!  Adelante! Los clientes esperan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you hire illegals--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Indignant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody is illegal in my cafe! They've  got green cards, they've got relatives  who were born here--if they only had  a little common sense I'd be very  happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you spent a little more time  training them--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you come here to tell me how to  run my business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was wondering if you'd like to  take a trip down south with us. Maybe  see where you grew up--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I want to go there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on--you must be curious how  it's changed. Amado is into this big  Tejano roots thing and I've never  been further than Ciudad Leon--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see Mexicans, open your  eyes and look around you. We're up  to our ears in them. Pilar gives up on the trip. She watches her mother poking the plates of chips and salsa ready to go out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mami, how old were you when my father--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. When he was killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little older than Paloma is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you never got married again? Mercedes just glares at her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must have been somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mutters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was too busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's too busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe now. It was different back  then. I had this place, I was doing  all the shopping, all the cooking.  What do I need some chulo with grease  under his nails to drink up the  profit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pissed off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean Fernando.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mami, the first time I brought him  home, those were your exact words--  "some chulo with grease under his  nails."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made it pretty damn clear you  thought he was nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt that you could do better for  yourself--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Become a nun? You didn't want  me going out with Anglos--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that. It was just that  boy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That boy"--Mami, say his name for  chrissakes! The employees are staring. Mercedes won't look at her dau as she steps out of the kitchen, banging into Enrique on way back in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people are stealing my money--  Entiende? Robandome? Mercedes is gone. The young girl, pulling plastic gloves looks to Pilar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Su madre? [Your mother?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. The girl puts her hand on her heart in sympathy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lo siento [My condolences.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded room, C&W MUSIC plays on the box. Sam sits a bottle of beer as the bartender, CODY, in his early 50s philosophizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm just as liberal as the next  guy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the next guy's a redneck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but I gotta say I think there's   something to this cold climate   business. I mean, you go to the beach- what do you do? Drink a few beers,  wait for a fish to flop up on the  sand. Can't build no civilization  that way. You got a hard winter  coming, though, you got to plan ahead,  and that gives your cerebral cortex  a workout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good deal you were born down here,  then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You joke about it, Sam, but we are  in a state of crisis. The lines of  demarcation has gotten fuzzy--to run  a sucessfull civilization you got to  have lines of demarcation between  right and wrong, between this one  and that one--your Daddy understood  that. He was like the whatchacallit-- the referee for this damn menudo we  got down here. He understood how  most people don't want their sugar  and salt in the same jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mixed drinks bad as you mix  metaphors, you be out of a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that pair over in the corner-- Sam swivels to look where Cody points--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place like this, twenty years ago,  Buddy woulda been, on them two--

dialogues.speaker: CORNER BOOTH
dialogues.text: Cliff and Priscilla talk across a table--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --warning. Not 'cause he had it in  for the colored

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but just as a kind of safety tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I bet he would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Sam stood for somethin', you  know? The day that man died they  broke the goddamn mold.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Things are obviously more than professional between these two--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where does that put us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--I don't see what's changed. No - PDA's, no necking on the obstacle  course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, I think we should get  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We been through this before--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should just do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I get a shot at a promotion  somewhere--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could take it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up or out these days, Cliff.  Say I get transferred to a different  post--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd quit the Army for you, if it  came to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man's gonna retire in two years and  he offer to quit. Big goddamn deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me-- They look up to see Sam standing over them--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff--hi--this is Sergeant--this  is Priscilla Worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Deeds was in on our  archeological find yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It true they gonna build a shopping  mall out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If certain people have their way,  it's going to be a new jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. Maybe we got in the wrong  business. They closin' down military  bases left and right, puttin' up  jails like 7-11 stores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do either of you have any idea when  they stopped using that site as a  rifle range?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stopped training infantry there  in the late '50s. It was just a  playground for the jackrabbits till  they gave it to the county last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who it was they dug up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for sure yet. But I kind of wish  they hadn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enrique steps out of the darkened cafe, followed by Merce who locks up. Mercedes steps over to an expensive-looking car--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Es muy lindo, su coche--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: En ingles Enrique. This is the United  States. We speak English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is very beautiful, your car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Enrique. She slides into  the car--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buenas noches, Senora Cruz. Enrique  walks in the opposite direction--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del, in uniform, approaches the front door of Big O's, no open for business yet. We TIGHTEN as he stops to read a  handlettered sign next to it: "BLACK SEMINOLE EXHIBIT REA ENTRANCE." He steps in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late-50s R&B plays on the JUKEBOX. Otis stands behind counter hooking the beer taps up. Del steps in and sits o stool at the far end of the bar, tense, looking around th place. When Otis sees him, he stops dead. They lock eyes a moment, then Otis turns to call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn--knock that off for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLYN
dialogues.text: CAROLYN SYKES, an attractive woman maybe ten years younge than Otis, pulls the plug from the jukebox near where she scrubbing bloodstains off the floor. She turns to look at the newcomer--

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Del doesn't move to come closer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black Seminoles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobby of mine. Got some artifacts,  couple pieces one of your men out at  the base made. Free admission. Del nods toward where Carolyn is mopping--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That where he was shot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where he fell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get much of that in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bar. People come together,  drink, fall in love, fall out of  love, air their grudges out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal drugs in the bathroom--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I thought it would help I'd put  up a sign telling them not to. Right  under the one about the employees  washing their hands. Carolyn has come over by Otis, lugging the bucket and mop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This here's Carolyn. Honey, this is  my son, Delmore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Ma'am. Carolyn nods, shoots a look to Otis--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be in back waiting for that  delivery. They wail till she is gone to start again--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me why I shouldn't make this  place off-limits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an official visit, then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume a lot of your business is  from our people. Otis pulls a tap back and it coughs before squirting beer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boys out there cooped up  together, need somewhere they can  let the steam out. If they're Black,  there's not but one place in this  town they feel welcome. Been that  way since before you were born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have an enlisted man's club at  the post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're the Man out there now,  aren't you? It's your call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
