dialogues.text: I been hearing rumors about this new  commander coming for a couple weeks  now. Boys say they heard he's a real  hard case. Spit-and-polish man. Full- bird colonel name of Payne, they say--  Bet you never figured you end up  back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Army hands you a command, you go  wherever it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear things, too.  People call   you the Mayor of Darktown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the years, this is the one place  that's always been there. I loan a  little money out, settle some  arguments. Got a cot in the back-  people get afraid to go home they  can spend the night. There's not  enough of us to run anything in this  town- the white people are mostly  out on the lake now and the Mexicans  hire each other. There's the Holiness  Church and there's Big O's place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And people make their choice--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of 'em choose both. There's  not like a borderline between the  good people and the bad people--you're  not either on one side or the other-- Del looks away, not wanting to believe this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gonna meet that family of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you want to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm your father. Del gives him a dark look and lets the statement hang bet them. He gets up and heads for the door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get official notification  when I make my decision. He is out  the door--Otis pulls himself a beer  as Carolyn steps back out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah--that's him. Got two, three  thousand people under him out there,  you count the civilians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be a laugh a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks down the main street of town. A CROWD is gather at the other end for the ceremony--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff! We WIDEN as H.L. and Jorge catch up to him. H.L. slaps Sa on the back--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Historic occasion, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like we have another one every  week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorge and his Chamber of Commerce  boys got to keep things hummin'--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're building up tourism, Sam--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People come here to catch bass and  to get laid at the Boy's Town in  Cuidad Leon--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to put up a banner-- "Frontera, Texas: Gateway to Cut- Rate Pussy"--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kind of talk doesn't help, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather have that than the ten-foot- high catfish statue--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got Eddie Richter at the Sentinel  to kill that story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Perdido thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He agreed it wasn't exactly news--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's gonna be out for blood the  next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is why we need to talk to you  about the new jail--just so we're  all on the same page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need a new jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a matter of interpretation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're already renting cells to the  Feds for their overflow--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a mandate in the last  election--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't happen to be your  construction company gonna get the  bid on building this thing, would  it, H.L. And Jorge, you wouldn't be  thinking about a couple dozen new  jobs to dangle in front of the voters--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, Sam, the people are concerned  about crime--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need a drug rehab program, we  need a new elementary school--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't money allocated for that.  But a jail--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not gonna campaign against  your deal here, but if anybody asks  me, I got to tell them the truth. We-- don't--need--a new jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we backed you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you backed me you needed   somebody named Deeds to bump the   other fella out of office.  Hey,   folks-- Sam and the others smile as they reach the CROWD of  townspeople, mostly small business owners and retired peo Photographers from the paper and a local TV news crew wai by a veiled Statue roped off in a little traffic island.  Mercedes, dressed to kill, stands waiting next to Hollis  with a huge pair of scissors in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CU MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Slowly working the blades of the scissors, she looks cold at Sam--

dialogues.speaker: CU SAM
dialogues.text: He nods to her as the crowd opens a path for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get this thing over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start on a two-foot-high statue of a cowboy made from bullets and shell casings. We PAN past a few others, the  poses lifted from Frederic Remington paintings, till we s Mikey, gluing together a work in progress, a Remington bo propped open in front of him. Cliff sits at the worktable playing absently with the old bullets spilled out from MI bag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never thought I'd see the day a buddy  of mine was dating a woman with three  up and three down on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's beyond what you'd call  dating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to get married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You met her family? They gonna be  cool about you being a white guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priscilla says they think any woman  over 30 who isn't married must be a  lesbian. She figures they'll be so  relieved I'm a man--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always heartwarming to see a prejudice  defeated by a deeper prejudice.  But  marriage, man--I did two tours in  Southeast Asia and I was married for  five years--I couldn't tell you which  experience was worse. Cliff picks up a slug--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mikey--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew she was Japanese going into  it, but she didn't tell me the ninja  assassin part--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her parents acted like I was gonna  blow my nose on their curtains--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I stayed out past ten with the  guys she'd go into her Madame  Butterfly routine--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey look at this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What--it's a bullet. I'm lousy with  bullets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a .45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the stuff we picked up the  other day, right? The rest of this  is all .30 caliber--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were using M-1's, yeah--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it doing on a rifle range? MIKEY holds the slug in front of his face--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better call that Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis is finishing his oration, having put the crowd in good mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometime in the early '70s a reporter  from a national magazine was talking  to the governor of our Lone Star  state, and he asked him, "Governor,  what's your ideal of what a real  Texan ought to be?" Governor said,  "That's easy, son- you just go down  to Rio County and get a look at  Sheriff Buddy Deeds." Applause--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Watching the crowd--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN with his gaze across smiling faces, till he comes Danny and a couple of Chicano friends, looking grim. We R FOCUS beyond them to see Pilar, watching the ceremony fro few yards back--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. We've got one more person  to hear from--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and he's somebody who probably  knew Buddy better than any of us,  Sam--would you say a few words?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Not thrilled to be called on. He steps forward reluctantl to APPLAUSE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks who remember my father  knew him as Sheriff. But at home he  was also judge, jury He looks to Hollis--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and executioner. LAUGHTER. Sam holds Hollis's eyes for a moment before  continuing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a real honor you're doing  him today, and if Buddy was around  I'm sure his hat size would be gettin'  bigger every minute.

dialogues.speaker: PILAR
dialogues.text: Watching--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to come to this park to hide  from him. Now that you're putting  his name on it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to find someplace new to  duck out. More LAUGHTER--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do appreciate it, and wherever he  is, Buddy's puttin' the beer on ice  for the bunch of you. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: APPLAUSE--
dialogues.text: Sam steps back and Mercedes steps forward with her scisso without looking at him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now my fellow Council member and  one of Frontera's most respected  businesswomen, Mrs. Mercedes Cruz,  will do the honors for us.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: She freezes, smiling, till the still photographers have g their shots, then snips the cord to a pulley system that  lets the cloth drop--

dialogues.speaker: STATUE
dialogues.text: The cloth drops to reveal a bas-relief in brass set in a  block of smooth limestone.  A decent likeness of Buddy in uniform, his hand on the shoulder of a small Chicano-look boy who stands beside him, eyes raised worshipfully. APPLAUSE from the gathering--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Watching, a bit removed, as Mercedes shakes hands with Jo and H.L. and Hollis for the cameras. He overhears a pair BYSTANDERS who are checking out the statue--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does look like old Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runnin that kid in for loiterin'-- The bystanders LAUGH--Sam steps away, intercepting Merced as she steps away--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you, Mrs. Cruz. Mercedes just looks at him, keeps going. His gaze brings to Pilar, standing on the sidewalk, watching.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Steps over from the dispersing crowd--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Field trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch hour. My next class isn't till  nine-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to take a walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and PILAR walk together alongside the Rio--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother still doesn't like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't name anybody she does like  these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see she built a place up here by  the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real palace. She rattles around  alone in that thing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's done well for herself--on her  own and all--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she tells me three times a week. She looks at him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you got through that pretty  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cooked the whole thing up without  asking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People liked him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people did, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember him watching me once.  When I was little--before you and I-- She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on the playground with all the  other kids, but I thought he was  only looking at me. I was afraid he  was going to arrest me--he had those  eyes, you know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird what you remember. They walk in silence a moment--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boy, there--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice-looking kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Paloma, it's more like she pities  and tolerates me- totally age- appropriate. But Amado--he's--he's  never been book-smart. Had a hard  time learning to read. Me being a  teacher and caring about those things  is like an embarrassment--like a  betrayal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fernando did okay, and he dropped  out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fernando wasn't pissed off at  everybody. He just wanted to fix  their cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might just be the age. I spent my  first fifteen years trying to be  just like Buddy and the next fifteen  trying to give him a heart attack. She looks at him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why did you come back here, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got divorced, I wasn't gonna work  for my father-in-law anymore. The  fellas down here said they'd back me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to be Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to admit it's not what I thought  it'd be. Back When Buddy had it-- hell, I'm just a jailer. Run a 60- room hotel with bars on the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can happen so sudden, can't it?  Being left out on your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got your mother, your kids--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got me. Different thing. They stop at a spot where you can climb down the bank--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember this? Pilar looks at the spot. She isn't ready to deal with wha memory it brings back--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks real bad if the teacher's late  for class. It's really nice to talk  with you, Sam. She waves and walks away, feeling awkward. Sam watches fo minute, then turns and steps down to the bank, He looks a the water.

dialogues.speaker: RIVER SURFACE
dialogues.text: A little piece of tree bark is tossed onto the water and  drifts away with the current. We TILT UP to see YOUNG PIL tossing bark into the river as YOUNG SAM sits on the bank beside her. They are 14 and 15 years old--It is 1972--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't need to know all my  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? What's he gonna do, arrest us? Young Pilar frowns, tosses more bark--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be some big sin,  even if you love each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: CU YOUNG PILAR
dialogues.text: She turns to look at him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We PAN with her gaze to see Sam, PRESENT DAY, sitting on bank, lost in thought--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Athena walking between buildings, looking a bit out of it Sergeant Worth cuts into her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private Johnson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Report to Dr. Innis at the clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm feeling okay--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very happy to hear that, Private.  Now you go put some pee-pee in a cup  for Dr. Innis and I'll be feeling  okay, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reacts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're testing me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and one hundred nineteen other  fortunate individuals. Put it in  gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sergeant. Sergeant Worth watches Athena go, suspicious--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Hernandez and another DEPUTY guide Shadow back in fro the courthouse in handcuffs--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent performance, my friend.  The judge was very impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to cuff me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been talking so much trash today,  you made us think you're a dangerous  criminal. Be a good boy, now-- They guide him past Sam's desk--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one who's a good boy. Man  say "fetch" and you fetch--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just doing my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White man just using you to keep the  Black man down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't Houston, my friend. We  pretty much running things now. Our  good day has come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suckers haven't had a good day  since the Alamo. Ray smiles, pushes him out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andale, amigo, We HOLD on Sam at his desk, TIGHTENING as he holds the .4 slug from the sergeants in front of his eyes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lupe? Get me the rangers up in Austin--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear old MEXICAN MUSIC. Ice cubes plunk into a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercedes, exhausted from a day at the cafe, pours herself Scotch and soda--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back LIGHT is flicked on and Mercedes steps out with drink in hand, the MUSIC audible from inside. She sinks i a recliner. We TIGHTEN as she closes her eyes. Something  RUSTLES out In the dark. Mercedes opens her eyes. There i WHISPERING. Mercedes sits up and suddenly two MEN run pas the edge of the patio toward the front of the house. Merc sighs--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otra vez los mojados--[Wetbacks   again--] Mercedes searches to find a portable phone on the patio t punches a number in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Border Patrol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, out of uniform, stands behind his little house chuck fallen pecans out into the dark, thinking, listening to t night sounds.

dialogues.speaker: CU SAM
dialogues.text: Working something out in his head. He looks off into the  dark and we PAN with his gaze--A MAN steps toward us, bar visible in the darkness. It is Charley Wade--We're in Sam REVERIE, in 1957--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that? Come out here where I  can see you! BLAM! A GUNSHOT, and Wade falls to his knees--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sonofabitch-- Wade falls on his face. A FLASHLIGHT BEAM flicks ON and p over his body. We PAN back along the be to see Buddy,  holstering his Pistol. He hears something, swings the  flashlight up.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We are back in 1995. Sam is blasted in the face with a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it right there! Brazos  arriba!  Sam, squinting toward the light to  see who it is, raises his hands over  his head--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that thing off 'im! He's one of  ours--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zack? The FLASHLIGHT BEAM PANS AWAY and ZACK POLLARD, a Border  Patrol agent, steps out of the dark to Sam--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Sam. Sorry 'bout that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had about a dozen wets come over  just upriver. They ran into one of  our posts--it was like a breakshot  on a pool table, illegals runnin'  every which way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen anybody come by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get 'em-- (Looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you livin' out here now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's quiet--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about that deal for your  father--You must be real proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stories people tell, he was a  real colorful fella--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zack! We got one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--back on the clock. You see any  of our neighbors from the south, let  'em know I'm lookin' for 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night-- Zack steps away.  Sam shakes the pecans still in his band goes back to chucking them--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Older CHICANO COUPLES dance to Mexican Music playing from speakers set up in the apartment complex courtyard.  We T UP to see Enrique watching from his window--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC still blasting.  Enrique steps away from the window and sits on the bed of his drab furnished apartment. He g back to tying knots in a length of clothesline splicing i to another. On the bed beside him are new flashlights and the batteries, still in their packaging. He begins to coi the rope--it is hundreds of feet long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar sits on her front Porch, listening to the MUSIC in distance. A woman singing a MEXICAN LOVE BALLAD. After a  while we hear Paloma open the screen door behind her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna stay out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a while. A silence. They listen to the RECORD--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she singing about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam has been up since dawn, searching through piles of ol department records. Papers cover his desk and the chairs  he's dragged over next to it. He reads out loud himself f a report in front of him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First bullet entered beneath the  left eye, severing the optical nerve  and exiting from top rear of skull  causing tissue damage

dialogues.speaker: DOCUMENTS
dialogues.text: As Sam reads, we see quick pops of various records--  Certificates of death. An old Sheriff's Department payrol An autopsy report. Eviction notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and severe cerebral hemorrhaging.  Second bullet entered left cheek   driving fragment of upper and lower  molars into base of skull. Third  bullet-- Real estate transfers. A map of the Proposed Lake Pescade Another autopsy report. A FAX COPY of the forensics denta report on Charley Wade. Another autopsy report--

dialogues.speaker: CU SAM
dialogues.text: Intent as he pores over the paperwork--

dialogues.speaker: LEGAL PAD
dialogues.text: We TILT DOWN to read various notes Sam has written--Reyna Garcia killed by Shf Wade--3/49 Hollis Kinney hired by Sh Dep.--9/51 Lucas Johnson k. by Shf Wade--7/53 Horace Gain k. by Shf Wade--1/54 Santiago Huerta k. by Shf Wade--4/54 Rifle range closed--9/56 Eladio Cruz k. by Shf Wade--12/5 Buddy Deeds hired by Shf Dep.--2/57 Shf Wade disappears-- 3/57 $10,000 cnty funds missing Buddy Deeds new Shf We come to Sam's hand, writing, when it clears we can rea the last entry-- Mercedes Cruz hired as cook, Rio Co. jail--4/57 ?????

dialogues.speaker: CU SAM
dialogues.text: Trying to put it all together. PETE ZAYAS, a skinny, older man in trustee's coveralls,  wanders in, emptying the trash baskets in the front offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Pete. How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time marches on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you got left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stop growing that loco weed at  your place, you'd see a lot more  daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was for personal consumption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to smoke an acre and a  half of marijuana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a bad stomach. It helps me  digest. Pete dumps out the basket by Sam--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father never bothered me about  it. Leastways not till the drug people  got on his back in the late '60s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he busted you a couple  times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different charge. I had a still.  Made my own mescal. Sam looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how I ruined my stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised he bothered with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was afraid I was going to poison  somebody. Your father tried to do  good for people--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I've heard--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your mother was a saint. That  summer I built the patio at your  house? She made me lunch every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you were working there--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could have just been a box lunch  from the jail. Sam looks up again, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You built our patio while you  were  on the county?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out in the fresh air, nice gringo  lady making you pies--who's gonna  sit back in a little jail cell all  day? Sheriff Buddy, man. Como el no  hay dos. And after that cabron Charley  Wade--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard Wade was a bit tough on  the Mexicans--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He murdered Eladio Cruz. That tough  enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdered him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chucho Montoya saw it with his own  eyes. Shot him in cold blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Hernandez, heading in to work, comes upon Sam getting into his car--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't seen much of you at the jail  lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been working on a few things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going over to the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Republicans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--to Mexico. I've got to talk to  somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got telephones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta be in person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. An awkward silence. Sam sits into the driver's seal and R leans down to talk--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam? I--the Committee--you know Jorge  and H.L. and all--they asked me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want you to stand for Sheriff  next election.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do a good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know if I'll still want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to be going around  your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate you telling me. Sam looks at his Chief Deputy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think we need a new jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a complicated issue-- Sam smiles, turns the engine on--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Ray, you'd be a hell of a  Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar sits with Amado on the football field bleachers bef school starts--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only going to have you for two  more years. If you decide not to go  on to college--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take any more school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --you're going to be on your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm worried about you. I don't  want you to end up in jail like your  friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not going to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to con me, Amado. You knew  how they got all those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just some rich Anglo out on the lake.  Don't even live here all year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes it okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stole our land--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save your breath. That line doesn't  cut it with me. A silence. Amado sulks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think you're going to  make a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fix cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can fix old cars. Mr. Washburn  told me that the cars they're making  now are all computerized--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I can't learn that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you can learn whatever you  want to. I just don't see you doing  it. If you want to settle for--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not settling for anything. I  like cars, it's just not a move up  the ladder to you, so you think it's  a waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That isn't true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on--you and Grandma think  anybody who works with their hands  is a peasant. When Dad--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you grew up to he anywhere near  as good a man as your father was, I  would be happy! I would be thrilled. They look, at each other for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my life. If I want to fuck it  up, that's my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said pretty much the same thing to  my mother when I was your age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years at hard labor, Our Lady of  Perpetual Help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catholic school, nasty. Pilar is nearly in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I think you're smart and you're  good and I love you. So don't act  like an idiot, all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Sam's car roll through the "express lane" as other cars in both directions stop by the inspection booths. Sa drives across the bridge over the Rio--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam drives slowly through the sprawling, more populous to on the other side.  Lots of the streets are unpaved.  We with the car till we HOLD on ANSELMA, a country girl of 1 aimlessly walking the streets--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch a KID about Amado's age pulling a tire off its r to put a patch on it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here we don't throw everything  away like you gringos do.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCHO AND SAM
dialogues.text: CHUCHO MONTOYA, in his mid-50s, stands by Sam drinking a  Coke as they watch the kid work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recycling, right? We invented that.  The government doesn't have to tell  people to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You own this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place, the one across the street,  four other ones around Ciudad Leon--  soy el Rey de las Llantas. King of  the Tires. Lots of your people rollin'  back over that bridge on my rubber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lived in the States for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen years in El Paso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made some money, came back here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever know a fella named Eladio  Cruz? CHUCHO smiles, draws a line in the dirt with his heel--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the sheriff of Rio County, right?  Un jefe muy respetado. Step over  this line. Sam obliges--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, que milagro! You're not the  Sheriff of nothing anymore- just  some tejano with a lot of questions  I don't have to answer. Sam smiles, plays with the line with his toe--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bird flying south-you think he sees  that line? Rattlesnake, javelina-- whatever you got--halfway across  that line they don't start thinking  different. So why should a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your government always been pretty  happy to have that line. The  question's just been where to draw  it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My government can go fuck itself,  and so can yours. I'm talking about  people here--men. Mi amigo Eladio  Cruz is giving some friends of his a  lift in his camion one day-- We PAN from CHUCHO to the FLAT TIRE on a battered old pic truck--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but because he's on one side of  this invisible line and not the other,  they got to hide in the back like  criminals-- Eladio CRUZ, young and good-looking, squats into the shot examine the tire, jack in hand. It Is 1956--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And because over there he's just  another Mex bracero, any man with a  badge is his jefe-- CONJUNTO MUSIC comes from the truck RADIO. YOUNG CHUCHO s past Eladio--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donde vas, Chucho, Tienes que quedar  escondido! [Shit, CHUCHO you got to  stay hidden!]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voy a romper las rinones si no hago  pipi--[I'm gonna bust my kidneys if  I don't pee--] We TRACK back with Young CHUCHO to see we are at the side a dirt road on the scrubby flatland near the border. Elad battered pickup truck has wood-slat sides and a canvas to Eladio begins to undo the nuts on the flat tire as Young  CHUCHO climbs down into a dry creek bed to relieve himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Los demas son tan espantados que  prefieran mojar sus pantalones. [The  other guys are so scared they'd rather  wet their pants.] CHUCHO tightens as he sees something, ducks down--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mira, Eladio [Look!] We PAN to see the Sheriff's car approaching in a cloud of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Calling from where  he lies changing the  tire)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muchachos! Escondases! [Boys! Hide  yourselves!]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight illegal WORKERS hear this and lie down, pulling a c tarp over themselves. We hear the CAR STOP behind them--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes the sign of the cross as he presses his back aga the dirt of the arroyo--

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Sheriff Wade and Deputy Hollis get out of their car and s toward Eladio--

dialogues.speaker: ELADIO
dialogues.text: He stands, takes a deep breath--Wade steps up to him with his hard-eyed smile--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hola, amgio. Problemas de llanta?  [Hey, friend. Tire problems?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hay de que. Tengo otra. [No   problem, I've got another.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in the back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Hollis strolls around the truck as if he's consider buying it.  He reaches in and flicks the RADIO OFF--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much, jefe. Some watermelons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard somebody been haulin' wets  on this road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen anybody doing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This same person been bragging all  over the county how he don't have to  cut that big gringo Sheriff in on it-- he can run his own operation 'thout  any help. Como se llama, amigo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eladio Cruz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this road got a bad  reputation, Eladio--

dialogues.speaker: ARROYO
dialogues.text: Young CHUCHO pecks over the edge to see what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reputation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandidos, Injuns--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis wanders over to stand by Wade--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's many an unfortunate soul  been ambushed out on this stretch.  Hope you're carrying some protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Protection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You carryin' a firearm, son?  Don't  lie to me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si--tengo escopeto--just a shotgun--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a shotgun, huh? Better let me  take a look at that. ELADIO opens the truck door and digs under the seat. Wade winks to Hollis, then turns and BLAM! shoots ELADIO throu the head. Hollis jumps back startled and horrified--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no--oh Jesus--oh my Lord--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little greaser sonofabitch been  running a goddarn bus service. Think  he can make a fool out of Charley  Wade! Get them wets outta the back,  Hollis, see what we've got--

dialogues.speaker: CU CHUCHO
dialogues.text: Squatting in a ball to make himself as small as possible, eyes covered with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a talent for statin' the  obvious, son Muchachos! Venga  afuera!Brazos arribas! [Come on out!  Hands up!] Young CHUCHO hears FOOTSTEPS approaching. We PAN as he lo a man's BOOTS appear at the top of the arroyo. We TILT UP see a Sheriff, BACKLIT, then CRANE to see it is Sam, back the PRESENT looking over the site, troubled. His car sits the empty road behind him. He frowns, turns to go--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody has spray-painted "PERDIDO!" over the plaque of  Buddy and the little boy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooligans--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis and a couple of MEN from the Public Work Departmen look at the damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens again, we build a fence  around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enrique steels himself, trying to cover his nerves. We CR with him to a booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Podemos ganar muchas batallas pero  la guerra ya es perdido--[We can win  a lot of battles but the war's already  been lost--] Zack and another BORDER PATROLMAN look up at him--

dialogues.speaker: CU ENRIQUE
dialogues.text: Eyes glued to his notepad--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wan' something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Georgia O'Keefe-looking cattle skull sits on a pedestal against the Western sky--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The longhorns go for ten times the  price-- We WIDEN as the skull is lifted by WESLEY BIRDSONG, a Nat American man in his 70s who wears extremely thick glasses Sam tags along as the old man rearranges the display of T curios laid out in front of his trailer. Empty scrubland  surrounds them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but longhorns are hard to come by  these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sell much out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I gonna sell things if nobody  comes by? This stretch of road runs  between Nowheres and Nothin' Much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a spot to put a business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't see much competition,  do you? He winks at Sam, picks up a wooden radio carved to resemb the Alamo--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These things used to sell like  hotcakes. Now, if it can't play those  discs, they won't look at it. He puts the radio on, looks out at the emptiness around--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it here. Once I tried going  onto that reservation to live.  Couldn't take the politics. Damn  Indian'll drive you crazy with that,  Now your father--this wasn't what he  had in mind at all. He come out of  Korea, he had this Chevy with too  much engine in it. He'd come roarin'  up and down this road all hours of  the day and night,looking for somebody  to race. He lifts a jar with a leathery brown thing in it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buffalo chips. Fella in Santa Fe  told me he sells these as fast as  the buffalo can squeeze 'em out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when did Buddy leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Frontera? Hell, I can't remember  dates no more. I do recall it was  after an affair of the heart had  gone sour on him. He almost took  some poor fella's head off at the  Legion in Arroyo Grande, and figured  it was time to move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he killed anybody in Korea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't hand those medals out for  hidin'in your foxhole. Would you buy  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither. He searches for something among the curios--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he hadn't found that Deputy job,  I believe Buddy might've gone down  the other path, got into some serious  trouble. Settled him right down.  That and your mother. 'Course he had  that other one later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother wasn't one to get chased  off her patch. Half the damn county  knew and nobody thought the worse of  her for seein' it through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who it was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other one? Hell, at my age, every  time you learn a new name you got to  forget an old one. Your head's all  crowded up--here it is-- Wesley stretches out a four-foot rattlesnake skin, rattle still attached--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This big fella was sleepin' in a  crate at Cisco's junkyard right when  I looked to see what was in it. Jumped  up at my face--scared me so bad I  killed him without thinkin'. He shakes the rattles at Sam--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta be careful where you're pokin'-- who knows what you'll find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PILAR talks with Molly as they near the administration of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you can take it  personally--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see them spend a day  pulling 14-year-olds off of each  other--I should get combat pay--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have new respect for some of my  kids, meeting the parents they've   been dealt-- Molly keeps going as Pilar ducks into the office--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you, Molly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PILAR crosses past the principal's secretary, MARISOL--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve called for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. Board of Education Steve who  likes you? He goes for us hot-blooded  Mexican girls, I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanish, please. My mother would  have a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother's family is Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, they go back to Cortez. When  he rode by, they were squatting in a  hut cooking hamsters for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to be interested in somebody.  All you do is work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my mother does is work. That's  how you get to be Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout the Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old-high-school-heartthrob  Sheriff. I thought you were crazy  about each other. He's available,  you're available--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm unmarried. I'm not available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me one time it was true  love. PILAR takes the pile of mimeos and mail from her slot and turns to go--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mutters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody stays in love for twenty-three  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is 1972. An early-'70s cheezy action picture (Filipino women-in-chains or biker flick is playing. We TILT DOWN t man's BOOTS crunching across the gravel of the parking ar Now and then, the man turns a FLASHLIGHT BEAM on a licens plate. The cars are all pre-'72, lots of pickups, and the patrons are almost all TEENAGERS. Some have turned their  pickups around to sit on the tailgate and watch, while ot have set lawn furniture out to sit on. We TILT UP slightl to see the glint of a Rio County Sheriff's badge pinned o the man's shirt. He meets a DEPUTY coming in the other  direction. Both train their FLASHLIGHTS on the license of the car we see in the b.g. between them.  We TILT and RAC to see that nobody is visible through the window--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. We FOLLOW Buddy up to the driver's side of the car as the Deputy goes to the passenger side. We PAN with Buddy's ha down to the door handle--he grabs it, flings it open--the overhead LIGHT flicks ON and there lie YOUNG SAM and PILA teenagers, half their clothes off and just about to close the deal. PILAR SCREAMS and the Deputy throws the door op by their heads--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit! Buddy grabs Sam's ankles and yanks him out of the car ont the ground as the Deputy awkwardly pulls PILAR, out the o side--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing? You  fucking asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is that girl? Goddammit,  where's your goddam sense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go!  Pendejo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now, Missy, get your clothes  in order-- Sam is trying to kick and punch at his father, pausing in between to pull his pants up. People are BOOING and HONKI their HORNS all around--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got no fuckin' right! You stay  out of my fuckin' life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the keys--gimme the goddamn  car keys, son--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I s'posed to do with her,  Buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drive her home and tell her mother  where we found her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam! The kids are dragged forward into the HEADLIGHTS that are being turned on to see what the ruckus is. Both are cryin struggling--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave her the fuck alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just shut that filthy mouth,  son. I'll deal with you when we get  home--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, don't tell my mother! She's  gonna kill me! They step closer into the glaring HEADLIGHTS which WHITE the scene, then FADE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is DUSK, PRESENT DAY. Our eyes readjust to see Sam,  standing by his car in the lot of the long-abandoned driv in. The ruined screen rises in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: CU SAM
dialogues.text: Remembering. MUSIC BEGINS as he gets back into the car, p away.

dialogues.speaker: MARQUEE
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES as the car cruises out past the old marqu a few letters still jumbled on it, several bullet holes a them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES as Sam drives, thinking--

dialogues.speaker: DUSK/NIGHT
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES as the car crosses the scrubland back tow town. DUSK turns to NIGHT--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES as Sam cruises past Pilar's house. The ca is not in the driveway: Paloma hangs out with a couple FR under the porch light, laughing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES as Sam's car pulls into the high school l He looks up toward the school--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES. We can see PILAR, through the lighted wi of her classroom, preparing something on the blackboard--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC ENDS as Sam leans back to wait--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PILAR digs in her bag for her car keys as she makes her w across the lot. She sees something, slows, reacting, then brings us to Sam in his car. He has parked head-to-foot n to hers. They look at each other for a long moment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing stirring. Pilar's car appears, closely followed b Sam's. The cafe has closed for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Pilar sit on chairs next to each other, facing th window, talking softly. The STREETLIGHT shining through t letters in the front window makes patterns on their faces

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought we were something, didn't  we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look at my kids in school--tenth,  eleventh graders. That's who we were.  Children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean what did we know about  anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Pilar looks at him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Nando died--it was so sudden--I  was kind of in shock for awhile.    Then I woke up and there was the  whole rest of my life and I didn't  have any idea what to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the other day, you asked  why I came back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came back 'cause you were here. PILAR nods. She gets up and we FOLLOW her across the dark room to the jukebox. She looks at the selections--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother hasn't changed the songs  since I was 10. She puts in a quarter, punches some numbers. A Mexican BA comes on. She crosses back to Sam, holds her hand out. He stands to greet her. They slow-dance in the empty cafe--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Pilar finish making love. They lie beside each ot shaking a little--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come it feels the same?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It just feels good.  Always did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are we gonna do about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More, I hope. PILAR smiles, looks around the room--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you lived here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing on the walls. No  pictures--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have kids. Other pictures--I  don't know--it's nothing I want to  look back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like your story is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've felt that way, yeah. Sbe puts her head on his cbest--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't. Not by a long shot. He  holds her and they lie silently for  a moment--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilar--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your father's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eladio. Eladio. Cruz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paloma sits on the top step of the porch, reading teen  magazines. PILAR steps out behind her, dressed casually, squints at the day--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finally got in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got in late last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I had uhm--school business. Paloma gives her a look, then holds a fashion page up for her to see--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody really wears that stuff,  Paloma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could name five girls at school  who have one just like it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough with the clothes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just 'cause you went to Catholic  school and wore a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only went for my last two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my mother wanted to keep me away  from away from boys. PILAR steps out into the sun--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis is sitting alone in a booth, working on some heuvo rancheros.  Sam slides in across from him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Hollis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam! Quite a do the other day. It  meant a lot to folks that you said  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought any more about our murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could tell you I remembered  something new, but I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an idea what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think somewhere between Roderick  Bledsoe's club and his house, Wade  ran into Buddy Deeds. I think Buddy  put a bullet in him, waited for him  to die, threw him in the trunk of  the Sheriff's car and drove him out  by the Army post, I think he buried  him under four feet of sand and never  looked back. Hollis sits back to look Sam in the eye--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lived in the man's house what-- seventeen, eighteen years? And you  didn't get to know him any better  than that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to go see somebody in San  Antonio today. Your memory gets any  better, I'll be back tonight. Sam stands and walks away. We HOLD on Hollis, his appetit gone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet steps around to the side entrance--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start on a statue of a BUFFALO SOLDIER made from spent bullets and shell casings, then PAN to another, then WIDE to see Chet as he pokes his head in, the BELL of the door ringing.  He steps in cautiously, looking around the room On the walls there are photo-blowups, some artifacts,  handlettered information on cardboard. Chet stops to look at a picture of a barechested Black man with a couple of  feathers stuck in his headband

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's John Horse. Chet turns to see Otis standing back by, the door from th bar--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanish in Florida called him Juan  Caballo. John Horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks at picture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He a Black man or an Indian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Steps in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both. Otis crosses to the poker table, begins to clean up--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was part of the Seminole Nation,  got pushed down into the Everglades   in pioneer days. African people who  run off from the slaveholders hooked  up with them, married up, had  children. When the Spanish give up  Florida, the U.S.Army come down to  move all them Indian peoples off to  Oklahoma--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trail of Tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They teaching that now?  Good. Only  a couple of 'em held out--this man,  John Horse, and his friend Wild Cat,  and a fella name of Osceola. Army  put all of them in prison and Osceola  died, but them other two escaped and  put together a fighting band and  held out another ten, fifteen years.  Beat Zach Taylor and a thousand troops  at Lake Okeechobee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they stayed in Florida?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got tired of fighting, went to  the Indian Territories for a while.  But the slave-raiders were on 'em  even there, and one night they packed  up and nearly the whole band rode  down to Mexico. Crossed at Eagle  Pass. They move on to some photos of very African-looking peopl dressed in beautiful Seminole clothing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men worked for Santa Anna down there,  waited out the Civil War. The land  wasn't much to feed people on, so in  1870 they come north and put up at  Fort Duncan and the men joined up  what was called the Seminole Negro  Indian Scouts. Best trackers either  side of the border. Bandits, rustlers,  Texas rednecks, Kiowa, Comanche--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fought against the Indians?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as they done in Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they were Indians themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were in the Army. Like your  father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a pretty good guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy who got shot--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't go telling your father  you were here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? And face a court- martial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a pretty tough old man, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sports if I don't keep a B average,  no TV on school nights, no PDA's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Public Display of Affection. Every  time he moves up a rank, it's like  he's got to tighten the screws a  little more--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, just 'cause he didn't--you  know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't have a father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still pissed off about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're his age you'll still be  pissed off about him. Chet nods, looks around--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how come you got into all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are our people. There were  Paynes in Florida, Oklahoma, Piedras  Negras--couple of 'em won the whatsit-- Congressional Medal Of Honor--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm part-Indian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By blood you are. But blood only  means what you let it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father says the day you're  born  you start from scratch, no breaks  and no excuses, and you got to pull  yourself up on your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's living proof of that,  son. Living proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Athena stands at attention as Del sits at his desk, revie her record. He lets her stand for a long time before spea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private Johnson, are you unhappy in  the Army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how would you explain the fact  that out of one hundred twenty people  we tested, you're the only one who  came up positive for drugs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you were given the opportunity  to enlist, a kind of contract was  agreed upon. I think the Army has  honored its part of that agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in what we're doing  here, Private Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I can do the job, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't sound too enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly do you think your job  is, Private?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow orders. Do whatever they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's "they"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The--the officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the job? Nothing about  serving your country? Athena is confused, hesitates to speak--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These aren't trick questions, Private.  You'll be given an Article 15 and be  going into the ADCAP Program one way  or the other. What happens after  that is up to you. I'm just trying  to understand how somebody like you  thinks. Silence--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Hesitant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really want to know, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's their country. This is one of  the best deals they offer. Del knows he asked for it, but doesn't like the answer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think I got to be a  colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work hard, be good at your job. Sir.  Do whatever they tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do whatever they tell you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, follow orders, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your attitude, Private, I'm  surprised you want to stay in the  service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Struggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside it's--it's such a mess--it's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos. Athena is sure she's overstepped her rank--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think they let us in on  the "deal"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got people to fight. Arabs,  yellow people, whatever. Might as  well use us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you've been discriminated  against on this post?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any serious problems with your  sergeant or your fellow soldiers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. They all been real straight  with me. Del stands, thinking, trying not to bullshit her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It works like this, Private--every  soldier in a war doesn't have to  believe in what he's fighting for.   Most of them fight just to back up  the soldiers in their squad--you try  not to get them killed, try not to  get them extra duty, try not to  embarrass yourself in front of them. He is right in her face now--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you start with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dismissed, Private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Athena salutes, steps out. Del looks out the window, trou by the encounter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battered car full of Mexican DAY WORKERS rolls toward t Mexican side checkpoint--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enrique sits squeezed between workers in the back. The dr never stops talking as the officer waves them through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Julia es demasiado flaca para mime  gusto mas mujeres con algo en frente--  o muy altas como Cindy Crofor.  Quisiera montar esa caballa--[Julia's  too skinny for me--I like women with  something up front--or really tall  like Cindy Crawford. I'd like to  ride that horse--]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam's car is parked on the street in front of an expensiv looking house in a tree-lined neighborhood--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam's ex-wife, BUNNY KINCAID, shuffles across her living  room in slippers, crossing to turn off a big-screen TV pl football highlights. Bunny wears shorts, a Houston Oilers sweatshirt and a Dallas Cowboys cap. The living room is l a sports museum-- signed footballs, team posters, a bookc filled with tapes of Texas pro and college football games

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Longhorns gonna kick some serious  butt this Saturday, you just watch.  We got a kid at tailback from down  your way--outta El Indio--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's in Maverick County. She brings us to Sam, sitting uncomfortably, beneath a fu sized blowup of Tony Dorsett hurdling a tackler--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. And you're in--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rio. BUNNY Right. This kid, Hosea  Brown? Does tire 40 in 3.4, soft  hands, lateral movement--the whole  package. Only a sophomore--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still going to all the home games?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Daddy's got his box at the  stadium, of course, and I'll fly to  the Cowboy away games when they're  in the Conference. Then there's the  high school on Friday' nights. West  Side got a boy 6'6", 310, moves like  a cat. High school, we're talkin'.  Guess how much he can bench-press?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny, you--uhm--you on that same  medication?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I seem jumpy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you look good. I was just  wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last year was awful rough--Mama  passing on and the whole business  with O.J.--I mean it's not like it  was Don Meredith or Roger Staubach  or one of our own boys, but it really  knocked me for a loop--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look good--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and that squeaker the Aggies dropped  to Oklahoma-sonofabitch stepped in  some lucky shit before he kicked  that goal--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --they hadn't pulled me off that  woman I would have jerked a knot in  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in a fight--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy calls it an "altercation." How  you doing, Sam? You look skinny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same weight I always was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look awful good in that uniform,  though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best part of the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy hired a pinhead to take your  job. He says so himself. Says "Even  my son-in-law was better than this  pinhead I got now".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny, is that stuff I left in the  garage still there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Least he never called me that. With  me, it was always "high-strung." "My  Bunny might have done something with  her life, she wasn't so high-strung."  Or "tightly wound," that was another  one. You seeing anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sort of. Daddy rounds 'em up.  You aren't talking about money, their  beady little eyes go dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't--uhm--you didn't have one  of your fires, did you? The stuff I  left in the garage--some of it was  my father's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch the draft this year? 'Course  you didn't, idiot question. They try  to make it dramatic, like there's  some big surprise who picks who in  the first round? Only they been  working it over with their experts  and their computers for months.  Doctor's reports, highlight reels,  coaches' evaluations, psychological  profiles--hell, I wouldn't be  surprised if they collected stool  samples on these boys, have 'em  analyzed. All this stuff to pick a  football player for your squad.  Compared to that, what you know about  the person you get married to don't  amount to diddly, does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kind of bought yourself a pig in  a poke, didn't you, Sam? All that  time we were first seeing each other  you didn't know I was tightly wound--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't just you, Bunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't, was it? You didn't  exactly throw yourself into it heart  and soul, did you? She looks at him for an uncomfortably long moment--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your shit's still in the garage if  that's what you came for. Sam nods, stands. Bunny is in tears--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 350 pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boy from West Side, plays tackle  both ways. Bench-presses 350 pounds.  You imagine having that much weight  on top of you? Pushing down? Be hard  to breathe. Hard to swallow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they have another fella there  to keep it off your chest. A spotter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I only got my little girl now," he  says, "she's my lifeline." Then he  tells me I can't be in the box anymore  if I can't control myself. Sonofabitch  don't even watch the damn game, just  sits there drinking with his bidness  friends, look up at the TV now and  then. I do better to sit in the cheap  seats with some real football people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Edging out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look good, Bunny. It's nice to  see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I like it when you say that,  Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enrique looks nervously over his shoulder before stepping into a funky apartment building. We TILT up to the second floor balcony, where a LITTLE BOY is watching the street-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are eight PEOPLE not including the little boy on th balcony. All are securing their possessions--rolling thin in blankets, filling shopping bags and grain sacks. Enriq steps in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todos estamos? [Everybody here?] Anselma reaches up from the floor to take his hand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van a disparar a nosotros? [Are they  going to shoot at us?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nadie nos veran. Seramos invisibles.  Nobody's going to see us. We'll be  invisible.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mess. We start on a campaign poster with Sam's face on and the legend--"ONE GOOD DEEDS DESERVES ANOTHER--VOTE SA DEEDS FOR COUNTY SHERIFF". We PAN to see Sam, who has bee digging through piles of old junk, set down the box he wa looking for--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam pulls out an old holster, a sheaf of real estate and  insurance forms, a couple of old paperback Zane Grey west He pulls out a cracked leather pouch, turns it over--lett fall out. He examines an envelope--no stamp or postmark-- pulls a letter out, reads--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dearest Buddy--" He puts the letter down for a moment, thinks. He needs to know. He picks the letter up again, reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn crosses the living room to answer the RING at the front door.  Del stands there--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel. Is uhm--is Otis in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's too late--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in. Del enters the house as if walking into an AMBUSH--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn sits back in the couch, drink in hand, checking D out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis sittin' up with some people at  the club. I don't think he'll be  long.

dialogues.speaker: CU DEL
dialogues.text: Uncomfortable, sitting at the edge of an easy chair. He l at a mounted magazine photo of Otis smiling as he pours h sauce on a rack of ribs--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hot sauce recipe won a contest  last year. They sellin' it far away  as San Antonio. He got a lot of  talent, your father. Del squirm a bit at the word "father"--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been in this house for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been here with him eight years  now. He built it when he was with  Leora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never met her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a bunch of 'em You never  met. Me neither. Del looks around the living room--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me show you around--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blowup of a photo of a squad of Buffalo Soldiers is mou on the wall--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got into all this cowboys and  Indians stuff awhile back. Spend  half his time pokin' around in the  library way up to Austin.

dialogues.speaker: CU DEL
dialogues.text: He looks at something below --

dialogues.speaker: CLIPPINGS
dialogues.text: We PAN slowly over laminated newspaper clippings mounted  behind a picture of young Del in a track uniform, holding vaulting pole. The clippings are about Del making honor r winning a Silver Star in Vietnam, graduating from Officer Candidate School, being named head of this and that in th Army--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of like a shrine, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, CAROLYN
dialogues.text: Carolyn stands behind, watching Del's face as he looks at the stuff--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd he get all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother got a brother--Alphonse--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Al--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis stood on good terms with the  man. Whenever you do something makes  the news, he sends it on. When they  made you General, Otis just about  drove away all our customers going  on about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know--Man made me memorize  the whole damn Army chain of command  before he'd marry me. So this is a  big deal, commander and  all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small post and they're phasing  it out in two years, but I moved up  in rank and--well, a command is a  command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis went on like you were that guy  who won the Gulf War. Colin whatsit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother said he never asked about--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never asked her. It's a bit too much for Del--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I uh--tell him I came by.  Thanks-- We HOLD on Carolyn as he hurries out. She salutes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch you later, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEOPLE, crouching low, wade across the river toward us. W he gets close enough to us, we recognize Enrique, nervous leading a group of Mexican men, women and children to the U.S. side. They are spaced out in the dark, loosely holdi the line Enrique made in one hand and holding their bundl high away from the water with the other. Enrique turns as hears a WOMAN'S CRY.  The line goes slack, then NESTOR st out of the darkness to join him--
